create a youtube clone that recommends you brainrot|||clone of youtube all features like likebutton follow channel adn monetiztion all features full youtube clone|||Make an identical youtube clone with all the videos|||Creating a YouTube clone with additional features like forums, polls, and voting for videos is a complex project that involves several steps. Below is a high-level overview of how you can approach building such a platform:
1. Planning and Design

    Define Requirements: Clearly outline the features you want to include (e.g., video upload, forums, polls, voting, user profiles, etc.).
    Wireframing: Create wireframes or mockups of the user interface (UI) using tools like Figma or Adobe XD.
    Data Flow: Design how data will flow between the frontend and backend.

2. Set Up the Development Environment

    Choose a Tech Stack:
        Frontend: HTML, CSS, JavaScript (use frameworks like React, Angular, or Vue.js for better performance).
        Backend: Node.js (with Express.js), Python (Django/Flask), or Ruby on Rails.
        Database: MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB (for NoSQL needs), or Firebase.
        Video Processing: Use FFmpeg for video transcoding.
        Hosting: AWS, Google Cloud, or other cloud providers for video storage and hosting.
    Set Up Tools: Install necessary tools like Git for version control, code editors (VS Code, IntelliJ, etc.), and testing tools.

3. Develop the Backend

    User Authentication:
        Implement user registration, login, and profile management.
        Use libraries like JWT (JSON Web Tokens) for secure authentication.
    Video Upload and Processing:
        Create an API endpoint for video upload.
        Use FFmpeg to transcode videos into different formats (e.g., MP4, WebM) for compatibility.
        Store videos on a cloud storage service like AWS S3 or Google Cloud Storage.
    Forum System:
        Design a database schema for forums, topics, and replies.
        Implement API endpoints for creating, reading, updating, and deleting forum posts.
    Polls and Voting System:
        Create a database schema for polls, questions, and votes.
        Implement endpoints for creating polls and recording votes.
    Video Voting System:
        Add a voting feature for videos (e.g., upvotes and downvotes).
        Store vote counts in the database and implement API endpoints to update and retrieve them.

4. Develop the Frontend

    User Interface:
        Build a responsive layout for videos, forums, and polls.
        Use a video player library like Video.js or JW Player for smooth video playback.
    User Interaction:
        Implement features like liking, commenting, and sharing videos.
        Design forum pages with threaded discussions.
    Poll and Voting UI:
        Create a visual representation of polls and their results.
        Add buttons or sliders for voting.

5. Integrate Videos, Forums, and Voting

    Video Embedding: Allow users to embed videos from other platforms (e.g., YouTube, Vimeo).
    Forum Integration: Link forums to specific videos or topics.
    Poll Integration: Embed polls within video pages or forums.

6. Moderation and Content Management

    User Moderation:
        Add features to report inappropriate content.
        Implement a moderation system where admins can review and remove harmful content.
    Content Management:
        Create an admin dashboard for managing users, content, and analytics.

7. Testing

    Unit Testing: Test individual components and functions.
    Integration Testing: Ensure that all features work together seamlessly.
    User Testing: Get feedback from real users to identify bugs and improve the user experience.

8. Deployment

    Hosting: Deploy your backend on a cloud platform like AWS, Heroku, or Google Cloud.
    Video Storage: Use a CDN (Content Delivery Network) like Cloudflare or AWS CloudFront for video storage and distribution.
    Domain and SSL: Purchase a domain and set up SSL for secure communication.

9. Maintenance and Scaling

    Monitoring: Use tools like Google Analytics or New Relic to monitor performance and user activity.
    Updates: Regularly update the platform with new features and bug fixes.
    Scalability: Optimize your database and server architecture to handle a growing user base.

10. Monetization (Optional)

    Ads: Integrate ad platforms like Google AdSense or create your own ad system.
    Subscriptions: Offer premium features like ad-free viewing or exclusive content.
    Partnerships: Collaborate with content creators for revenue sharing.

Additional Tips:

    Use Existing Libraries: Leverage existing libraries and frameworks to save time (e.g., Express.js for backend, React for frontend).
    Learn from Open Source: Look for open-source projects similar to YouTube and learn from them.
    Focus on Usability: Ensure the platform is intuitive and user-friendly.

Example Tech Stack for a YouTube Clone:

    Frontend: React.js with TypeScript, Redux
    Backend: Node.js (Express.js), NestJS, or Python (Django/Flask)
    Database: PostgreSQL, MySQL, or MongoDB
    Video Processing: FFmpeg, AWS S3, or Google Cloud Storage
    Authentication: Auth0, Firebase, or JWT
    CDN: Cloudflare, AWS CloudFront
    Hosting: AWS EC2, Heroku, or DigitalOcean|||generate a youtube clone with dummy placeholders|||a youtube clone but with 5 star rating and cimment section that supports images no provide the whole website|||create a Youtube clone Change the font color to black (not black black but a dark gray color) and add images to the thumbnail|||a robot chicken tv, where i can see youtube robot chicken clips all night please research and add real existing youtube videos please add live api to search videos existing on youtube and put them randomly in the list, keyword "Robot Chicken" please without public youtube key|||create a youtube clone which shows us a youtuber profile with a few videos he/she uploaded. Costly sneakernet chat app: It has fields for username and message, and then larger fields for "input" and "output" (whose function will be explained shortly). When the user hits "send", the app puts the message and current date, and proof-of-work data into a JSON format (format: {"message": message, "date": date, "powData": data}), where the proof-of-work data is just a random number that was chosen so that the SHA1 hash over the whole JSON has zeros as its last two letters. This JSON gets put into the "output" field. The user can paste such JSONs into the "input" field and the app will evaluate whether the date is within an hour of the current date and whether the proof-of-work is correct (i.e. whether the SHA1 hash over it ends in two zeros), and only display the user's message in the chat history if that's the case. His story:
Robert is a small, silly, ginger kitten with a knack for causing chaos and making everyone laugh. He has a peculiar habit of sitting on his bottom like a tiny little man, which is both adorable and hilarious. Whenever someone touches his bottom or after he gets a bath, he grumbles in a deep, comical murmur, sounding just like an old man grumbling ("mr-mr-mr"). When he has an upset stomach and needs to clean himself, he amusingly scoots on his bottom across the floor.

One of his most distinctive features is a funny ginger splotch on his face that makes him look perpetually ridiculous. Robert loves to play around and is incredibly mischievous. He has a penchant for stealing random items off the table, like bottle caps, that he has no real use for. He's also notorious for swiping food, fully aware that he's not supposed to, but doing it anyway with a cheeky defiance.

Despite his naughty streak, Robert is incredibly affectionate. He often curls up on mother, purring contentedly, and follows his humans everywhere like a little shadow. He's particularly fond of begging for food, jumping onto father's lap to purr and coax some treats from him. Occasionally, Robert goes into a frenzy, tearing around the house and knocking over everything in his path.

Though he can be a bit of a rascal, sometimes biting father for no apparent reason, he never bites mother and seems to be quite intimidated when she scolds him. Robert might not always listen to father, but he‚Äôs undeniably a loving and cuddly kitten at heart.|||a social network for dogs|||build a cat patting website, where users can come, select a cat and pat it with animation. Description of win 95:
Answer
Windows 95 introduced a revolutionary user interface that significantly changed how users interacted with their PCs. It combined simplicity with functionality, making it accessible to both novices and experienced users. Here's a detailed description of its key visual and functional elements:
The Desktop
The desktop was the central workspace, designed to mimic a real-world desk. It featured a clean and organized layout with graphical objects like icons for quick access.
Default desktop icons included:
My Computer: Provided access to drives, printers, and system settings.
Network Neighborhood: Allowed users to browse networked computers.
Recycle Bin: Served as a temporary storage for deleted files, enabling easy recovery.
My Documents: A folder for storing personal files.
Users could add shortcuts to applications, files, or folders by dragging them to the desktop134.
The Taskbar
Positioned at the bottom of the screen by default, the taskbar was a defining feature of Windows 95.
It displayed:
The Start button, which opened the Start menu.
Buttons for each open application or window, allowing easy task switching.
A notification area (system tray) showing background applications, volume control, and the clock1415.
The Start Menu
The Start menu was a major innovation, providing a centralized hub for accessing programs, documents, settings, and help.
Key sections of the Start menu included:
Programs: A cascading menu listing installed applications.
Documents: Quick access to recently used files.
Settings: Access to system settings like Control Panel and Printers.
Find/Search: A tool for locating files or folders.
Help: An improved help system for troubleshooting and guidance.
Shutdown: Options to turn off or restart the computer4515.
Icons and File Management
Icons were visually distinct and could represent programs, folders, or shortcuts. Users could customize their placement on the desktop.
File management was handled through Windows Explorer, replacing the older File Manager. It allowed users to navigate directories in a tree-like structure and offered drag-and-drop functionality34.
Minesweeper
Minesweeper was one of the pre-installed games on Windows 95. It featured:
A grid-based puzzle where players clicked tiles to uncover numbers or mines.
Numbers indicated how many mines were adjacent to a tile, while clicking on a mine ended the game.
Difficulty levels ranged from Beginner (8x8 grid) to Expert (30x16 grid)211.
Visual Design
Windows 95 introduced a beveled "3D" look for windows, buttons, and menus. This aesthetic made the interface appear more modern compared to its predecessor, Windows 3.13.
The color scheme typically featured shades of gray with blue highlights for selected items.
Other Features
The system supported cascading windows that could be minimized, maximized, or resized. Users could tile or cascade windows for multitasking3.
Hidden file extensions and system files aimed to simplify file management for beginners but could be revealed by advanced users if needed3.
AutoRun functionality was introduced for CDs, automatically launching setup programs when inserted into the drive4.
Windows 95's combination of the Start menu, taskbar, desktop shortcuts, and intuitive file management set a new standard for operating systems. Lite 3 is very similar to tic-tac-toe, with the change that each player can only have at most three of their markers on their board at a time.

The board starts empty. One player places X markers and the other player places O markers.

To move, choose an empty cell of the grid to place a marker. If you already have three markers on the board, then your least recently placed marker will disappear as soon as you have placed your newest marker, leaving its cell empty so that players can place a marker there in the future.

The user should be able to input a matrix and vector expression using variables and syntax that you define (and display to the user). The program would then calculate the symbolic gradient of this expression with respect to a given variable name. Note that the user needs to specificy if a given variable is a scalar, vector, or a matrix. For instance, the input could be  `x. y` where `x` and `y` are vectors, the dot `.` after `x` denotes the transpose, i.e. the expression is the inner product of `x` and `y`. Taking the gradient with respect to `x`, the output should be `y` (a column vector, in matrix calculus there are different orientations for gradients, we choose the column orientation). The variable can be any letter. You should add a function to guess the intended type of the variable. For instance, all capital letters can be guessed to be matrices, letters starting from "u" in alphabetical order should be interpreted as vectors, and other letters as scalars. The user should be able to simply input the expression and the variables would be automatically detected and given their assumed types. The user could then modify them if needed. - **Campus Life:** A vibrant section highlighting student life, extracurricular activities, and campus facilities, with engaging images and testimonials.

- Follow **modern UI/UX principles** with intuitive navigation and accessibility in mind.  
- Use **clear typography** and high-quality images to enhance engagement.

**Prompt:**

"Design a modern and responsive university website UI that showcases the institution's academic programs, research initiatives, and campus life. The website should cater to prospective students, current students, faculty, and staff.

**University Name:** Aurora University
**Motto:** "Illuminate Your Horizon" (reflecting the idea of yellow and blue colors coming together to represent a bright and limitless future)

**Color Scheme:**

1. **Primary Color:** Yellow (#F7DC6F)
2. **Secondary Color:** Blue (#3498DB)
3. **Accent Color:** Dark Gray (#333333) for text and backgrounds
4. **Background Color:** White (#FFFFFF) or Light Gray (#F7F7F7) for main content areas

**Key Features:**

1. **Hero Section:** A prominent banner showcasing the university's logo, motto, and a call-to-action (CTA) to encourage visitors to explore the website.
2. **Navigation Menu:** A user-friendly menu that allows visitors to access main sections such as Admissions, Academics, Research, Campus Life, and About Us.
3. **Programs and Courses:** A section highlighting the university's academic programs, including undergraduate and graduate degrees, certificates, and online courses.
4. **Research and Innovation:** A section showcasing the university's research initiatives, including faculty profiles, research centers, and publications.
5. **Campus Life:** A section featuring student organizations, events, and campus resources, such as libraries, recreation centers, and support services.
6. **News and Events:** A section displaying university news, upcoming events, and announcements.
7. **Call-to-Actions (CTAs):** Prominent CTAs throughout the website to encourage visitors to apply, request information, or contact the university.
8. **Footer:** A footer section with essential links, contact information, and social media links.

**Design Requirements:**

1. **Typography:** Use a clean, modern sans-serif font (e.g., Open Sans, Montserrat) for body text and a serif font (e.g., Merriweather, Georgia) for headings.
2. **Imagery:** Use high-quality images that showcase the university's campus, students, and faculty, with a focus on yellow and blue accents to reinforce the brand identity.
3. **Responsive Design:** Ensure the website is fully responsive and accessible on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.
4. **Accessibility:** Follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.1) to ensure the website is accessible to users with disabilities.

**Deliverables:**

1. A fully functional UI design concept
2. A style guide outlining the color palette, typography, and imagery usage
3. A responsive design that adapts to different screen sizes and devices

**Target Audience:**

1. Prospective students
2. Current students
3. Faculty and staff
4. Alumni and donors

Organized Density: The image is packed with information, yet the eye can still discern individual elements. We need a similar approach to content presentation. We want to create a purely experimental website focused on the visual concept of stacked signage, inspired by the dense layering of signs in the provided image. Think of the website itself as a digital interpretation of that wall of signs ‚Äì a place where different pieces of content and interactive elements are layered and presented in a visually engaging way. This isn't about selling anything; it's about exploring a design aesthetic and user interaction.

Key Design Inspiration & Requirements (Focusing on Stacked Signage):

Digital Sign Stacks: The core idea is to represent website content as stacked "signs." These could be different sizes, shapes, and orientations, mimicking the variety in the image.

Interactive Layers: Users should be able to interact with these "signs." Think about ways to reveal content by:

Clicking or hovering on a sign to bring it to the front or expand it.

Dragging and rearranging signs to create their own compositions.

Scrolling through layers of signs, creating a sense of depth.

Visual Hierarchy through Stacking: The stacking itself should communicate hierarchy. Perhaps signs at the top are more prominent or contain primary information.

Content as Signs: The "signs" can contain various types of content:

Short text snippets.

Images or icons.

Simple interactive elements (like buttons that trigger animations).

No Clear Path: Unlike a typical website, there shouldn't be a rigid navigation structure. The exploration and interaction with the stacked signs is the navigation.

Visual Interest and Texture: Mimic the visual texture of the image. Develop a fully functional, responsive **Generic Markers Management Dashboard** using the **Boosted Framework (version 5.3)** by Orange. The solution must adhere to the following technical and performance specifications:

---

### **1. Technical Specifications**
- **Responsive Design**: Use a mobile-first approach to ensure seamless usability across all devices.
- **Cross-Browser Compatibility**: Guarantee consistent behavior on major browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge).
- **Accessibility**: Fully comply with **WCAG 2.1 AA** accessibility standards.
- **Performance Optimization**: Optimize loading and interactions for a smooth user experience.
- **Error Handling and Validation**: Implement robust client-side error handling and form validation.
- **Internationalization**: Ensure the design and components can adapt to multiple languages and regions.

---

### **2. Performance and Security Requirements**
- **Minimize DOM Manipulation**: Keep the number of reflows and repaints minimal for better performance.
- **Lazy Loading**: Use lazy loading for components and assets to optimize page load time.
- **Secure Data Inputs**: Sanitize all user inputs to prevent XSS vulnerabilities.
- **Client-Side Validation**: Validate inputs in real time to enhance security and usability.
- **Optimized Asset Loading**: Use Boosted's utilities to load only essential assets and scripts efficiently.

---

### **3. Dashboard Overview**
Build an **interactive, enterprise-grade HTML dashboard** for managing "Generic Markers," styled and optimized using Boosted 5.3. The dashboard must contain:

#### **Header Section**
- Title: **BO Profiling**.
- Navigation Menu: Tabs for **TV Markers**, **Genetic Profiles**, **Advertising Markers**, **Advertising Measurement**, **Events**, and **Admin**.
- User Info: Display the logged-in user ("dvu") on the top-right with a **Logout** button.

#### **Generic Markers Section**
- Title: **Generic markers**.
- Display the **Last Update** date (e.g., **12/12/2024**) highlighted in green.
- Add a **Search/Filter Bar** for dynamically filtering the table content.
- Action Buttons:
  - **Delete Selected**
  - **Toggle Activation**
  - **Add a Marker**
  - **Export**
  - **Add Marker Wha**

#### **Table Layout**
The table should display and manage marker data with the following columns:
- **Select**: Checkbox inputs for multi-row selection.
- **Type**: Icons (use Boosted enterprise-grade icons) representing marker types.
- **Name**: Unique marker names (e.g., *th_actif_bein_sport*).
- **Title**: Descriptive marker titles.
- **Flag**: Labels like `channel x` displayed as red badges.
- **Threshold**: Integer thresholds.
- **End Date**: Dates formatted consistently (e.g., **12/12/2024**).
- **Min Zap**: Integer inputs (e.g., **300**).
- **Clients**: Client identifiers (wildcard "*" where applicable).
- **Count Method**: Text values like `MINUTES` or `VIEWS`.
- **Volume**: Display large numerical counts (e.g., **23304**).
- **Processed**: Display processed dates.
- **Edited**: Show the last edited timestamps.
- **Audience**: Labels like **OPTIN Reco**.
- **Activation**: Toggle switch to enable/disable markers.
- **Actions**: Icons for actions like edit/delete.

#### **Styling and Accessibility**
- Use **Boosted Framework's grid system** and components for layout.
- Ensure all table rows and buttons are fully keyboard-navigable.
- Add tooltips, ARIA labels, and focus states for accessibility compliance.
- Style the **Last Update** and **Flag** columns with Boosted utility classes (e.g., `badge-danger` for flags).
- Ensure clean spacing, alignment, and hover effects for buttons.

---

### **4. JavaScript Interactivity**
Use **Vanilla JavaScript** to implement the following functionalities:
- **Dynamic Filtering**: Allow users to filter table rows based on keywords.
- **Row Selection**: Multi-row selection using checkboxes.
- **Toggle Activation**: Toggle marker activation status on the fly.
- **Validation**: Validate all user inputs when adding or editing markers.
- **Error Handling**: Display error messages for invalid actions.
- **Lazy Loading**: Load additional table rows or content only as needed.
- **Export Functionality**: Provide a downloadable export (e.g., JSON/CSV).

---

### **5. Deliverables**
- A **responsive HTML dashboard** structured with Boosted 5.3.
- Modular and reusable **CSS components** integrated from Boosted.
- Functional **Vanilla JavaScript** for interactivity and performance optimizations.
- Comprehensive **documentation** explaining:
  - Component usage.
  - Design rationale.
  - Scalability considerations.

---

### **6. Design Considerations**
- Prioritize a clean, professional layout with a clear visual hierarchy.
- Ensure a seamless user experience with intuitive navigation and consistent design language.
- Design for scalability and adaptability, keeping future extensions in mind.

This deliverable must be optimized for both **performance** and **security** while maintaining an enterprise-grade look and feel.|||<guideline>
Design Requirements:

- Theme: Dark mode with #1A1A1A background and #333333 component backgrounds
- Accent colors: Primary (#4CAF50 for success/active states), Secondary (#FF4444 for alerts/badges)
- Font: Inter or system-default sans-serif, 14px base size
- Spacing: Consistent 16px/24px padding and margins
- Use a clean, modern, and responsive design with a consistent look and feel across all screens.
Ensure all UI elements, typography, and spacing follow established design patterns and principles.
- Incorporate data visualization components (charts, graphs, etc.) to provide at-a-glance insights.
- Optimize the user experience for both power users and occasional administrators.
- Provide clear, intuitive navigation and workflows to minimize cognitive load.

Technically, the backoffice should:

- Be built as a Single Page Application (SPA) using the React framework.
- Leverage a state management solution like Redux or MobX to maintain a consistent application state.
- Implement responsive design using a CSS-in-JS library like Styled Components or Emotion.
- Incorporate Shadcn UI component library to accelerate development.
- Utilize RESTful APIs to communicate with a backend server for data management.
- Implement role-based access control and authentication to secure the application.
- Provide comprehensive logging, error handling, and monitoring capabilities.
- Be optimized for performance, accessibility, and SEO.

Interaction Requirements:

- Responsive layout (minimum width 1200px)
- Smooth hover transitions (0.2s)
- Loading states for async operations

Accessibility:

- ARIA labels for interactive elements
- Keyboard navigation support
- High contrast text (minimum 4.5:1 ratio)
- Focus indicators for interactive elements

Error States:

- Clear validation messages
- Loading placeholders
- Empty state design
- Error boundary handling
</guideline>

The dashboard includes a header, navigation tabs, a main content area with an info bar, and a data table with various functionalities like sorting, filtering, and bulk actions.|||## **Tech Stack**

### **Front-End**

- **Framework**: React (or Next.js for server-side rendering and SEO benefits)
- **State Management**: Redux Toolkit or Zustand (for simplicity)
- **UI Library**: Material-UI or Tailwind CSS
- **Charts & Analytics Visualization**: Chart.js or D3.js
- **Testing**: Jest & React Testing Library

### **Back-End**

- **Framework**: Node.js with Express (scalable, high-performance REST APIs)
- **Language**: TypeScript (ensures type safety)
- **Authentication**: Auth0 (for SSO, 2FA, and social logins)
- **Real-Time Updates**: WebSocket (Socket.io for event-driven features)
- **Job Queue/Processing**: Bull.js with Redis (for asynchronous tasks like A/B test automation)

### **Database**

- **Relational Database**: PostgreSQL (robust for complex queries and data integrity)
- **NoSQL Database**: MongoDB (for storing unstructured data like content or logs)
- **Caching**: Redis (for low-latency data retrieval)
- **Search**: Elasticsearch (for advanced filtering and search capabilities)

### **Cloud Infrastructure**

- **Hosting**: AWS (EC2 for compute, S3 for storage, RDS for relational database, DynamoDB for NoSQL)
- **CI/CD**: GitHub Actions or GitLab CI/CD
- **Monitoring**: Datadog or New Relic
- **Containerization**: Docker and Kubernetes

### **Third-Party Tools**

- **Email & Notification**: Twilio SendGrid (for emails) and Firebase (for push notifications)
- **Payment**: Stripe (for subscription management)
- **Analytics**: Google Analytics & Mixpanel (for user behavior)

---

## **Development Plan**

### **1. Initial Setup**

- **Set Up Repositories**: Use Git/GitHub for version control and CI/CD.
- **Environment Setup**:
    - Use Docker for containerization.
    - Create `.env` for managing environment variables securely.
- **Authentication Module**: Implement Auth0 for secure user authentication.

---

### **2. Build Front-End**

1. **Set Up React**
    - Scaffold your project using Create React App or Next.js.
    - Configure Material-UI or Tailwind CSS.
2. **Build Landing Pages**
    - Create signup/login pages.
    - Integrate 14-day free trial workflows.
3. **Dashboard**
    - Build the Campaign Hub with a real-time performance dashboard.
    - Use Chart.js for KPI widgets.
4. **Campaign Calendar**
    - Create a calendar component with conflict detection.
    - Implement drag-and-drop using libraries like `react-beautiful-dnd`.

---

### **3. Build Back-End**

1. **API Design**
    - Use RESTful conventions or GraphQL for flexible queries.
    - Define endpoints for campaign creation, updates, analytics, and integrations.
2. **Authentication**
    - Set up user management with Auth0, including role-based access control.
3. **Data Models**
    - Design PostgreSQL schemas for campaigns, users, and channels.
    - Use MongoDB for dynamic campaign assets.
4. **Workflow Automation**
    - Implement custom automation rules with Node.js and Bull.js for background jobs.
5. **Platform Integration**
    - Add API integrations for Facebook, Google, and others using SDKs.
    - Set up webhooks for real-time updates from third-party platforms.

---

### **4. Add Advanced Features**

1. **Real-Time Features**
    - Use Socket.io for live updates on campaign performance.
    - Integrate push notifications using Firebase.
2. **Dynamic Budget Optimization**
    - Build machine learning models using Python (scikit-learn or TensorFlow).
    - Train models offline, deploy them as REST APIs (e.g., using Flask or FastAPI), and call them from your backend.
3. **Analytics**
    - Set up Elasticsearch and Kibana for competitive intelligence dashboards.
    - Add multi-touch attribution modeling.

---

### **5. Testing & Deployment**

1. **Testing**
    - Unit testing: Jest (frontend) and Mocha/Chai (backend).
    - Integration testing: Postman or Newman for API workflows.
    - End-to-end testing: Cypress.
2. **CI/CD Pipeline**
    - Automate testing, building, and deployment with GitHub Actions.
3. **Deploy**
    - Use AWS for hosting (EC2/S3) and database (RDS).
    - Configure a load balancer for scalability.

---

### **6. Launch & Iterate**

- Gather user feedback via Mixpanel and Google Analytics.
- Prioritize new features based on user needs.
- Continuously monitor system health using Datadog.|||Okay, let's break this down into a detailed prompt designed to get you the best possible MERN stack web application for your movie recommendation service. This prompt will cover features, functionalities, data modeling, and user roles, aiming to provide clarity for a developer.

**Here's the Detailed Prompt:**

**Application Overview:**

Develop a MERN (MongoDB, Express.js, React, Node.js) web application for a physical DVD movie rental/purchase service that provides personalized movie recommendations and inventory management features. The application will have distinct user roles (general users, administrators, and sales personnel) with varying levels of access and functionality. The core functionality revolves around matching new movie stock with user preferences and facilitating sales processes.

**Core Features & Functionality:**

1.  **User Management (All Users):**
    *   **Registration/Login:** Secure user authentication system allowing users to register accounts (general users), administrators to create accounts (for other admins and sales personnel). The service is paid so the admin will create the users and set payment status.
    *   **Profile Management:** Ability for users to manage their profile information, including email, and potentially other details (though not vital initially, future scalability is good).
    *   **Password Management:** Password reset functionality with secure processes.

2.  **Movie Preferences (General Users):**
    *   **Preference Setting:** Allow users to specify their movie preferences including:
        *   **Genre (e.g., Action, Comedy, Sci-Fi, Horror, etc.)** (Use a dropdown, maybe allow multiple selections)
        *   **Release Year or Range (e.g., 1990s, 2000-2010, etc.)** (Use a slider or dropdown)
        *   **Age Rating (e.g., G, PG, PG-13, R, etc.)** (Use a dropdown)
        *   **Actors/Directors (Optional, but nice-to-have for the future).** (Use a searchable input)
        *   **Keywords:** A searchable input for more specific requests.
    *   **Preference Storage:** Secure storage of user preferences in the database.

3.  **Inventory Management (Administrators and Sales Personnel):**
    *   **Add New Movies:** Admin functionality to add new movie titles, including:
        *   **Movie Title** (text input)
        *   **Genre(s)** (dropdown, multi-select)
        *   **Release Year** (number input)
        *   **Age Rating** (dropdown)
        *   **Actors/Directors** (optional, text input with commas or searchable dropdown)
        *   **Description/Synopsis** (text input, multi-line)
        *   **Image URL/Upload** (image upload/URL option)
        *   **Physical Media Stock Level** (number input)
    *   **Movie Stock Tracking:**
        *   **Status:** Display a movie's current status (Available, Reserved, Sold, Pending, Finance, etc.)
        *   **Status Management:** Update the status of a movie.
    *   **Sales Person Assignment:** Track which sales person has a movie in their queue, should be tracked via a user object and saved on the movie item
    *   **Status Hover:** When hovering over the status it should display the sales person's name.
    *   **Search and Filtering:** The system should have an easy and fast search function, it should also be able to filter by status and sales person.

4.  **Recommendation System (Backend and Notifications):**
    *   **Matching Algorithm:** Implement a logic that compares new movie entries with existing user preferences.
    *   **Notification System:** When a close match is found (defined by the matching algorithm) the system sends a notification to the relevant Sales team user's dashboard. The match can be a specific one, or a more relaxed preference to be more broad.
    *   **Dashboard Notifications:**
        *   Display new match notifications to the dashboard.
        *   Should give key info like the movie, and how close the user match is.
        *   Allow the sales person to click it and navigate to the movie item page.

5. **Admin Panel (Administrators):**
    *   **User Creation:** Admin function to add new users with a status (Admin or Sales Staff), email, and password.
    *   **User Payment Status:** Add functionality to track payment status for each user, to see if they are an active or inactive user.
    *   **User Management:** Admin to disable users, or change user roles.
    *   **User Searching:** Search for users via email, user status, and user role.
   

**User Roles:**

*   **General User:** Can register, log in, set preferences, and (potentially in future) view recommendations (but no purchase or actions on the status).
*   **Sales Personnel:** Can log in, view new movie stock, see notifications, manage movie statuses (e.g., Reserve, Sold, etc.) and should be tracked on each item.
*   **Administrator:** Can log in, add users and manage user payments, add movie inventory, manage user statuses, manage all movie statuses, and should not be able to track their own sales status.

**Technical Specifications:**

*   **Frontend:** React with a suitable component library for UI elements (e.g., Material UI, Chakra UI, Ant Design, or similar). Responsive design is required.
*   **Backend:** Node.js with Express.js for API development.
*   **Database:** MongoDB (or equivalent) for storing user data, movie data, and match information.
*   **Authentication:** Secure JWT (JSON Web Tokens) or similar authentication implementation for secure access.
*   **API Endpoints:** Design a set of RESTful API endpoints for data retrieval and manipulation between the frontend and backend.
*   **Error Handling:** Implement robust error handling both on frontend and backend.

**Data Modeling (Example Schema):**

*   **Users:**
    *   `_id`: ObjectId
    *   `email`: String (unique, required)
    *   `password`: String (hashed, required)

    *   `paymentStatus`: String (e.g. "paid", "unpaid")
    *   `createdAt`: Date
    *   `updatedAt`: Date

*   **Movies:**
    *   `_id`: ObjectId
    *   `title`: String (required)
    *   `genres`: [String] (array of genre strings)
    *   `releaseYear`: Number (required)
    *   `ageRating`: String (required)
    *   `actors`: [String]
    *   `directors`: [String]
    *   `description`: String
    *   `imageUrl`: String
    *   `status`: String (e.g., "Available", "Reserved", "Sold", "Pending", "Finance")
    *   `salesPerson`: ObjectId (reference to User document)
    *   `createdAt`: Date
    *   `updatedAt`: Date

*  **Recommendations (Example Structure - Might be dynamic):**
    *   `_id`: ObjectId
    *   `user_id`: ObjectId (reference to User document)
    *   `movie_id`: ObjectId (reference to Movie document)
    *   `matchScore`: Number (number or string for closeness)
    *   `createdAt`: Date

**Important Considerations:**

*   **Scalability:** Design the system to be scalable as the user base and inventory grow.
*   **Performance:** Optimize for speed and efficient data retrieval, and rendering.
*   **Security:** Implement proper security measures for data storage, data transfer, and user management.
*   **UI/UX:** Focus on creating an intuitive and user-friendly interface.

**Deliverables:**

*   Fully functional MERN application meeting all requirements.
*   Complete codebase with proper comments.
*   Database schema design.
*   API documentation for all endpoints.

   - Use a relational database such as PostgreSQL or MySQL for storing blog posts, user data, comments, tags, and categories.
   - Create tables for blog posts, users, comments, and categories.

3. **User Authentication:**
   - Use JWT (JSON Web Tokens) for secure authentication.
   - Implement user roles (admin, writer, reader) with appropriate access controls.

4. **Post Management:**
   - Create endpoints for CRUD operations on blog posts (Create, Read, Update, Delete).
   - Handle file uploads (images) for blog posts.

5. **Comment Management:**
   - Implement an endpoint to handle comments on blog posts.
   - Include features for managing comment approvals, deletions, and replies.

6. **Search & Filter:**
   - Create an endpoint to handle search functionality across posts using keywords or tags.
   - Implement sorting by date or popularity.

7. **Email Notifications (Optional):**
   - Set up email notifications for new posts or comments (e.g., using SMTP or third-party services like SendGrid).

8. **Security & Best Practices:**
   - Secure the application using HTTPS and SSL/TLS encryption.
   - Protect against common vulnerabilities (e.g., SQL injection, XSS attacks, CSRF).
   - Ensure password hashing and storage using bcrypt or similar libraries.

const UserSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  username: { 
    type: String, 
    unique: true, 
    required: true 
  },
  email: { 
    type: String, 
    unique: true, 
    required: true 
  },
  password: { 
    type: String, 
    required: true 
  },

    type: String,
    enum: ['USER', 'ADMIN', 'MODERATOR'],
    default: 'USER'
  },
  favorites: [{ 
    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId, 
    ref: 'Anime'

    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
    ref: 'WatchHistory'
  }],
  notifications: [{
    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
    ref: 'Notification'
  }]
}, { timestamps: true });

  title: { 
    type: String, 
    required: true 
  },

  description: String,
  genres: [String],
  status: {
    type: String,
    enum: ['ONGOING', 'COMPLETED', 'UPCOMING']
  },
  startDate: Date,
  endDate: Date,
  totalEpisodes: Number,
  seasonName: String,
  source: String,
  trailerUrl: String,
  malUrl: String,
  coverImage: String,
  bannerImage: String,
  rating: Number,
  episodes: [{
    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
    ref: 'Episode'
  }],
  recommendations: [{
    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
    ref: 'Recommendation'
  }]
}, { timestamps: true });

// Episode Schema
const EpisodeSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  number: Number,
  title: String,
  duration: Number,
  releaseDate: Date,
  anime: {
    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
    ref: 'Anime'
  },
  servers: [{
    name: String,
    embedUrl: String
  }]
}, { timestamps: true });

// Release Schedule Schema
const ReleaseScheduleSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  anime: {
    type: mongoose.Schema.Types.ObjectId,
    ref: 'Anime'
  },
  dayOfWeek: {

  },
  releaseTime: Date

System Architecture Considerations with MongoDB
Database Advantages

Flexible Schema: MongoDB's document-based model allows easy schema evolution
Horizontal Scalability: Built-in sharding capabilities
Performance: Efficient for read-heavy applications
Complex Query Support: Powerful aggregation framework

Indexing Strategy

Create compound indexes on frequently queried fields
Use text indexes for search functionality
Implement partial indexes for optimization

Authentication Workflow

User Registration


Validate email (prevent Gmail dot trick)
Hash passwords with bcrypt
Implement Cloudflare Turnstile
Store user credentials securely


OAuth Integration


NextAuth.js for Google/Discord login
Store OAuth tokens securely
Implement token refresh mechanism

Caching Layer

Redis for caching frequent queries
Implement cache invalidation strategies
Use Redis for session management

Recommendation System

Genre-Based Recommendations


Analyze user's favorite anime genres
Use MongoDB aggregation for matching
Implement collaborative filtering

Admin Panel Features

Comprehensive Management Interface


Anime CRUD operations
Episode management
Media control
Slide show configuration
Branding customization
User role management

Performance Optimization

Query Optimization


Use projection to limit returned fields
Implement efficient indexing
Leverage MongoDB aggregation pipeline
Use lean() for read-heavy operations


Caching Strategies


Redis caching for frequent queries
Implement cache-aside pattern
Use MongoDB change streams for real-time updates

Security Considerations

Data Protection


Implement role-based access control
Use encryption for sensitive data
Validate and sanitize all inputs
Implement rate limiting


Authentication Security


JWT with short expiration
Refresh token mechanism
Implement multi-factor authentication

Deployment Architecture

Containerization


Docker for consistent deployment
Separate containers for:

Next.js Frontend
NestJS Backend
MongoDB
Redis




Hosting Infrastructure


Ubuntu VPS
Nginx as reverse proxy
SSL with Let's Encrypt
Cloudflare for CDN

Monitoring and Analytics

Error Tracking


Sentry for real-time error monitoring
Custom analytics dashboard
User interaction insights


Performance Monitoring


Prometheus for metrics collection
Grafana for visualization
Log aggregation with ELK stack

Basic Anime and Episode Management
User Profile and Favorites
Recommendation Engine

security guidelines, ensuring robust protection against vulnerabilities while focusing on essential 
functionalities that can be practically implemented within limited resources.
2. MVP Features
Core Functionalities
1. User Authentication
o Secure login with username and password.
o Basic Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for admin users.
2. File Management
o Upload, view, search, edit, and delete files.
o Metadata management (e.g., file name, category, subcategory).
3. Search and Retrieval
o Metadata-based search with basic keyword matching.
4. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
o Manage roles (Admin, Editor, Viewer) to control access to functionalities.
5. Audit Logging
o Log user activities and file operations.
6. File Encryption
o Encrypt files with AES-256 before storage.
o Enforce secure file transmission with HTTPS.
3. Development Phases
Phase 1: Planning and Requirements Gathering
1. Define Functional Requirements:
o Finalize MVP features with stakeholders, prioritizing essential functionalities.
o Identify specific OWASP security measures to implement.
2. Define Non-Functional Requirements:
o Set clear expectations for performance (e.g., file upload size, search response time).
o Plan for modular scalability.
3. Technology Stack Selection:
o Frontend: React.js for responsive UI.
o Backend: Node.js or Django for scalable API development.
o Database: PostgreSQL for metadata, MongoDB for logs.
o Storage: Amazon S3 or local secure file storage.
o Security Tools: Libraries for JWT-based authentication, OpenSSL for encryption.
Phase 2: Architecture Design
1. System Architecture:
o Use a three-layered architecture: Presentation, Application, and Data Layers.
o Focus on modularity to allow incremental enhancements.
2. Security Framework:
o Embed OWASP guidelines into the architecture (e.g., validate inputs, secure session 
management).
o Design encryption workflows for file storage and transmission.
Phase 3: Development
1. Frontend Development:
o Build intuitive UI for file upload, search, and role-based dashboards.
o Implement input validation on the client side using libraries like Yup.
2. Backend Development:
o Create REST APIs for file operations and user management.
o Implement RBAC to enforce access control policies.
3. Database Integration:
o Create schemas for structured metadata storage.
o Store audit logs in MongoDB for flexibility.
4. Encryption Implementation:
o Integrate AES-256 for file encryption before storage.
o Ensure TLS 1.3 for all network communication.
Phase 4: Security Implementation
1. Input Validation:
o Sanitize and validate all user inputs using backend libraries like Joi.
2. Authentication and Authorization:
o Use JWT tokens for session management.
o Enable MFA for admin roles.
3. Audit Logging:
o Record all critical operations (e.g., file access, deletions) with timestamps.
o Ensure logs are tamper-proof by adding integrity checks.
4. Transport Security:
o Configure HTTPS with TLS 1.3 for secure data exchanges.
5. Access Control:
o Enforce RBAC at the API level to ensure that only authorized actions are performed.
Phase 5: Testing and Validation
1. Functional Testing:
o Validate core features like file upload, search, and RBAC.
2. Security Testing:
o Perform OWASP-recommended tests:
‚ñ™ SQL Injection using automated tools.
‚ñ™ XSS testing by manipulating input fields.
‚ñ™ Session fixation tests.
o Tools: OWASP ZAP for automated vulnerability scanning.
3. Performance Testing:
o Test response times for file operations under expected load conditions.
4. User Acceptance Testing (UAT):
o Validate the system with real users for feedback and final adjustments.
Phase 6: Deployment and Documentation
1. Deployment:
o Deploy the MVP on a cloud platform like AWS or Azure with basic monitoring enabled.
o Use Docker containers for scalability and ease of deployment.
2. Documentation:
o Write concise user manuals for admins and end-users.
o Document APIs for developer reference.

5. Deliverables
1. Fully functional MVP with:
o Secure user authentication and RBAC.
o File management (upload, search, retrieval, delete).
o Secure file encryption and logging.
2. Compliance with essential OWASP standards.
3. Comprehensive documentation for users and developers.
6. Tools and Technologies
1. Frontend: React.js.
2. Backend: Node.js
3. Database: PostgreSQL (structured metadata), MongoDB (logs).
4. Encryption: OpenSSL, AES-256.
5. Testing Tools: OWASP ZAP, Postman for API testing.
6. Deployment: Docker, AWS.|||Create a  a fully functional blogging webapp with essential features like user authentication, CRUD operations for posts, and responsive design, all connected through a robust backend.

<guideline>
Design Requirements:

- Theme: Dark mode with #1A1A1A background and #333333 component backgrounds
- Accent colors: Primary (#4CAF50 for success/active states), Secondary (#FF4444 for alerts/badges)
- Font: Inter or system-default sans-serif, 14px base size
- Spacing: Consistent 16px/24px padding and margins
- Use a clean, modern, and responsive design with a consistent look and feel across all screens.
Ensure all UI elements, typography, and spacing follow established design patterns and principles.
- Incorporate data visualization components (charts, graphs, etc.) to provide at-a-glance insights.
- Optimize the user experience for both power users and occasional administrators.
- Provide clear, intuitive navigation and workflows to minimize cognitive load.

Technically, the backoffice should:

- Be built as a Single Page Application (SPA) using the React framework.
- Leverage a state management solution like Redux or MobX to maintain a consistent application state.
- Implement responsive design using a CSS-in-JS library like Styled Components or Emotion.
- Incorporate Shadcn UI component library to accelerate development.
- Utilize RESTful APIs to communicate with a backend server for data management.
- Implement role-based access control and authentication to secure the application.
- Provide comprehensive logging, error handling, and monitoring capabilities.
- Be optimized for performance, accessibility, and SEO.

Interaction Requirements:

- Responsive layout (minimum width 1200px)
- Smooth hover transitions (0.2s)
- Loading states for async operations

Accessibility:

- ARIA labels for interactive elements
- Keyboard navigation support
- High contrast text (minimum 4.5:1 ratio)
- Focus indicators for interactive elements

Error States:

- Clear validation messages
- Loading placeholders
- Empty state design
- Error boundary handling
</guideline>

You specialize in accounting software integrations and are tasked with creating a prototype for an e-conomic extension that helps bookkeepers and accountants handle dividend taxation across multiple countries.

Objective:
Build a multi-step web application that enables users to quickly enter, review, and integrate dividend data into e-conomic, while handling manual input and CSV uploads efficiently.

Step 1: User Flow & Features
1. Landing Page (Step 1: Data Entry)
Users can manually enter dividend details (ISN number, country code, net and gross amounts, currency).
System automatically determines tax rates based on the country.
Option to upload CSV files with dividend transactions for bulk processing.
CSV Mapping UI: Users can map CSV columns to required fields.
2. Review Page (Step 2: Overview & Adjustments)
Displays a summary of dividends per country.
Allows manual adjustments to tax rates (e.g., changing 15% to 30% for US dividends without a QI agreement).
Highlights which taxes can be reclaimed via self-reporting vs. the bank.
3. Economic Integration (Step 3: Posting to Economic)
Users select accounting settings, including:
Chart of accounts for gross dividends.
Account for Danish & foreign withholding tax (posted to liabilities).
Refund tracking for reclaimable tax.
Generates PDF reports summarizing transactions.
Posts transactions directly to Economic via API.
Step 2: Tech Stack & Implementation
Frontend (Next.js & React)
Multi-step form with state management via Context API or Redux.
CSV handling using PapaParse or csv-parser.
Form validation with Yup or React Hook Form.
Backend (Node.js & Express)
REST API for managing transactions.
Integration with Economic API for posting transactions.
CSV processing in the backend with fast-csv.
Database (PostgreSQL or MySQL)
Tables for dividends, tax rates, and user settings.
Caching frequently accessed data (e.g., country tax rates) for performance.
Step 3: Development Plan
Set up Next.js project with React Context for multi-step navigation.
Develop Step 1: Input Forms & CSV Upload (with validation).
Build Step 2: Review Page with dynamic calculations.
Implement Step 3: Integration with Economic API.
Test End-to-End Flow with sample data.
Deploy MVP for user feedback.
Output Expected from AI
A React + Next.js codebase with a multi-step form.
CSV import functionality with field mapping.
Basic database schema for tracking dividend transactions.
Economic API integration for posting transactions.
PDF report generation for tax filings.|||UI request:

are you ready for the tasks? (Programming II) you will be creating a
drawing application. A screenshot of the final product of your work is shown in figure 1 below
and its functionality was demonstrated to you in the first lecture.
Figure 1: A screenshot of the drawing application.
The task of constructing the above drawing application will occupy our CSC-20037 lab-
classes for several weeks at the start of the course. Throughout this exercise you will gain
valuable experience in Graphic User Interface (GUI) design/construction.
The task of creating the above application has been broken into sets of incremental tasks. It
will become increasingly difficult to start each week‚Äôs practical if you haven‚Äôt completed the
previous one. You should ask for help if you encounter difficulties and seek confirmation
that you are on the right track, from the practical demonstrators and your lecturers.
It is also important that you study your lecture notes and all the examples
accompanying them before attempting your practical tasks.
Download and unzip the NetBeans project DataStructuresExamplesLecture2 file from the
KLE. The simple programs in this zip-file show some primitive GUI-oriented examples that
create window frames and attach some different Java layout managers so that you can start to
experiment with how they work.
School of Computing and Mathematics
CSC-20037 Programming II
Page 2 of 5
For this week‚Äôs set of practical tasks you need to familiarise yourself with the four main
regions/areas in the drawing application window. These are:
1. The canvas panel
2. The control panel
3. The message area panel and
4. The menu bar.
The canvas is where the user of your application will be drawing graphic objects such as lines,
rectangles, ovals or freehand traces.
The control panel will contain various options for drawing (such as providing a choice of
drawing tool, drawing size etc.) and options for assisting drawing (such as switching on/off
the grid, showing the mouse coordinates etc.) For now, do not be concerned with the contents
of the control panel.
The message area panel will host a text area in which messages can be posted for the user.
Again, do not be concerned with the text area itself but only with the panel that will contain it.
Finally, the menu bar provides the means to perform different actions (such as the
saving/loading of the canvas contents etc.) by making selections from an organised menu. In
this practical you will be expected to only create the different menu choices but not to
implement any of the actions they describe.
Task 0
Having downloaded and unzipped the NetBeans project DataStructuresExamplesLecture2
file. Make sure you execute and try to understand each line of the source code for each
of these example programs before you move on to the tasks below. You should refer to
the last few slides of the lecture notes from Lecture 2 and to the online Java documentation
for some of these Java Swing GUI classes: to get a good idea of how these sample programs
are working.
Task 1
Create the application window (using the JFrame class) and give it a suitable title. Also, give
your window a starting size that is small enough to stay within the bounds of your screen but
big enough to be easily visible.
Why don‚Äôt you run your program and see if you get the result you expect.
Task 2
Following the creation of the application window, create three panels (using the JPanel
class) that will form the canvas, the control panel and the message area.
School of Computing and Mathematics
CSC-20037 Programming II
Page 3 of 5
To be able to distinguish the panels from each other, when you come to place them in the
application window, you can either change their background colour or give them a labelled
border. The following instructions explain how you can add a border to your panels.
The code fragment below shows you how to do this for the canvas panel:
...
JPanel canvas = new JPanel();
canvas.setBorder(new TitledBorder(new EtchedBorder(), "Canvas"));
...
(N.B. in order to access the nice to have features of an ‚Äòetched border‚Äô etc. on the canvas
component of your program you will need to import the specialist
javax.swing.border.* sub-package, in addition to the usual classes from the swing
and awt packages.)
Also, each panel needs to be given a starting size. For now, give all panels a width of 200
pixels and a height of 100 pixels. For example:
...
canvas.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(200, 100));
...
Following their creation and customisation (border and size) add the three panels to the
application window (without changing the default layout manager) using the add method. For
example:
...
add(canvas);
...
Run your code and inspect the result.
Task 3
The default layout manager for the JFrame class is the FlowLayout. How does this layout
manager manage GUI components? Does this behaviour agree with how your program works?
Change the layout manager of your application window to the BorderLayout manager.
Place the three panels created in the previous task using this layout manager. You will also
need to change the size of each panel in order to achieve a result that resembles the screenshot
in figure 2.
School of Computing and Mathematics
CSC-20037 Programming II
Page 4 of 5
Figure 2: Result using the BorderLayout manager.
Task 4
The menu bar should provide the following choices:
The ‚ÄúFile‚Äù menu should have choices: ‚ÄúSave‚Äù, ‚ÄúLoad‚Äù and ‚ÄúExit‚Äù and
The ‚ÄúHelp‚Äù menu should only have choice: ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù.
Choice ‚ÄúSave‚Äù will (at a later stage) be implemented so that it saves the canvas contents in a
file. ‚ÄúLoad‚Äù will read/recall any saved contents from the file, ‚ÄúExit‚Äù will simply exit the
drawing application and ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù will produce a small dialog window giving some
information about the drawing application.
In order to implement the menu bar you first need to create a JMenuBar object and add it to
its container (in this case the application window). Then you need to create each menu (from
the JMenu class) and add them to the JMenuBar object. Finally, you need to create each
menu item (from the JMenuItem class) and add those to their corresponding JMenu
object. It all sounds more complicated that it really is.
Here is some code to get you started:
...
JMenuBar menuBar = new JMenuBar();
JMenu fileMenu = new JMenu("File");
JMenuItem fileSaveMenuItem = new JMenuItem("Save");
fileMenu.add(fileSaveMenuItem);
menuBar.add(fileMenu);
...
... // Add the menuBar object to its container here.
Task 5
School of Computing and Mathematics
CSC-20037 Programming II
Page 5 of 5
Why don‚Äôt you try and add a few GUI components (buttons, labels, checkboxes, radio buttons
and a slider) in the control panel.
Do not worry about responding to any component behaviour at the moment. Can you arrange
them in different layouts, resize them etc.?
Also, try to create and add a text area component (from the JTextArea class) into the
message area panel created above.|||Design a canvas with tools for drawing shapes, lines, and adding text. this represents the consumer (end-user) journey participating in the V2G product: Energy Management: Switch between downloading and uploading energy with real-time price monitoring to control energy flow effectively. Automated Scheduling: Configure automatic charging or selling based on predefined price conditions and adjust battery target levels and reserves. Battery Charge Target and Discharge Limits: set battery levels on the vehicle to not go above when charging X%, and not go below when uploading energy to the grid below Y%, ensuring a healthy state of charge for personal mobility needs. Mobile First Interface: Receive notifications for optimum time of charge/discharge and use it on both desktop and mobile devices. Expenditure, Incentive, and Achievements Tracking: Monitor spend on charging, income and achievements (like badges for social good and quantification of the positive impact) earned by participating in the V2G program.|||Single-Screen Mobile App for Real-Time Home Energy Tracking 1. Data Requirements Primary Data Points: Category Metrics Source Solar Current Production (kW) Daily Total (kWh) Inverter API Home Current Usage (kW) Solar Contribution (kW) Grid Contribution (kW) Total Consumed (kWh) Smart Breaker + Calculations Grid Current Import (kW) Current Export (kW) Daily Export (kWh) Calculated Values System Voltage (V) Current (A) Total Energy (kWh) Smart Breaker Update Frequency: Auto-refresh every 5-10 seconds Manual refresh option (optional)|||an energy tracking software, in this software, as active energy reactive energy tracking, the total amount of energy consumed in that year, the amount of penalties will be seen, you can also see these energy amounts by month. That makes sense for a mobile interface. They mentioned using React, so I'll focus on React components, but since it's using Canvas, maybe they're looking for something more graphical or animated. The data points are "acpower", "yieldtoday", "yieldtotal", "feedinpower", "feedinenergy", and "consumeenergy". These seem related to energy production, maybe solar or similar. So the dashboard should display these metrics clearly. They want a minimal design, so I should suggest a clean layout. Maybe a dark theme since it's easier on the eyes, especially for a glance view. Using a dark background with contrasting text and elements would make the data stand out. For the layout, a top navigation bar with a title and a refresh button makes sense. Then, the main data points can be displayed in cards. Maybe two columns of cards, each showing a specific metric with a value and a unit. Icons next to each metric would help visually distinguish them. Including a line chart to show today's energy production over time would add context. Using a library like Chart.js with Canvas renderer could work well for smooth animations and interactions. Styling preferences should be modern and clean. Maybe using Roboto for typography since it's clean and readable. Colors like blue for highlights and gray for backgrounds would keep it minimal. Interactions are important. The user should be able to tap on metrics to see more details, and the chart should show a tooltip on hover. A pull-to-refresh gesture would let them update the data easily. Responsive design is key for mobile, so it should look good on different screen sizes. The layout should adjust, maybe switching to a single column on smaller screens.|||

Attention Is All You Need
Ashish Vaswani, Noam Shazeer, Niki Parmar, Jakob Uszkoreit, Llion Jones, Aidan N. Gomez, Lukasz Kaiser, Illia Polosukhin
The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks in an encoder-decoder configuration. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.|||Create a cnn filter visualizer.|||Generating a simple website visualize the upsampling layer|||Designing deep learning architecture Add example CNN model|||create a visualisation of a convolutional neural network which processes an image as input. class SimpleNeuralNetwork:
    def __init__(self, input_size, hidden_size, output_size):
        # Initialize weights with random values
        self.weights1 = np.random.randn(input_size, hidden_size)
        self.weights2 = np.random.randn(hidden_size, output_size)
        
    def sigmoid(self, x):
        return 1 / (1 + np.exp(-x))
    
    def sigmoid_derivative(self, x):
        return x * (1 - x)
    
    def forward(self, X):
        # Forward propagation
        self.hidden = self.sigmoid(np.dot(X, self.weights1))
        self.output = self.sigmoid(np.dot(self.hidden, self.weights2))
        return self.output
    
    def backward(self, X, y, output, learning_rate=0.1):
        # Backward propagation
        self.output_error = y - output
        self.output_delta = self.output_error * self.sigmoid_derivative(output)
        
        self.hidden_error = np.dot(self.output_delta, self.weights2.T)
        self.hidden_delta = self.hidden_error * self.sigmoid_derivative(self.hidden)
        
        # Update weights
        self.weights2 += np.dot(self.hidden.T, self.output_delta) * learning_rate
        self.weights1 += np.dot(X.T, self.hidden_delta) * learning_rate
    
    def train(self, X, y, epochs=1000):
        for _ in range(epochs):
            output = self.forward(X)
            self.backward(X, y, output)

# Example usage
if __name__ == "__main__":
    # XOR problem
    X = np.array([[0,0], [0,1], [1,0], [1,1]])
    y = np.array([[0], [1], [1], [0]])
    
    # Create and train network
    nn = SimpleNeuralNetwork(2, 4, 1)
    nn.train(X, y)
    
    # Test the network
    for i in range(len(X)):
        prediction = nn.forward(X[i:i+1])
        print(f"Input: {X[i]}, Predicted Output: {prediction[0]}, Actual Output: {y[i]}")|||Make a neural network visualizer|||Could youbuild a fancy introduction page for this paper?

Rotary embeddings, also known as RoPE (Rotary Position Embedding), is a method of encoding positional information in transformer models, particularly those used in natural language processing. 

**Key Concepts**

* **Positional Information:** In transformer models, it's crucial to provide information about the position of words in a sequence. Traditional methods like adding positional encodings can have limitations.
* **Rotation Matrix:** RoPE uses rotation matrices to encode absolute positional information. This method also naturally incorporates explicit relative position dependency in the self-attention mechanism.
* **Properties:**
    * **Flexibility:** Can be applied to sequences of any length.
    * **Decaying Dependency:** The influence of inter-token relationships decreases with increasing relative distances.
    * **Relative Position Encoding:** Can equip linear self-attention with relative position encoding.

**How it Works**

1. **Frequency Array:** An array of frequencies is initialized using exponential scaling to generate rotation factors.
2. **Position-Based Scaling:** Positions are scaled by these frequencies.
3. **Rotary Matrix:** A rotary matrix is created using the scaled angles.
4. **Embedding:** The rotation matrix is multiplied with the original vector to embed positional information.

**Advantages**

* **Captures Relationships:** Effectively captures relationships between words based on their relative positions.
* **Efficiency:** Computationally efficient, especially for long sequences.
* **No Fixed Length Limitations:** Can handle sequences of any length, unlike some other positional encoding methods.
* **Improved Performance:** Often leads to improved performance in tasks like machine translation and language modeling.

**In Simple Terms**

Imagine a clock with multiple hands, each representing a word in a sentence. RoPE is like giving each hand a unique way to rotate based on its position in the sentence. This way, the model can understand the order of the words and how far apart they are from each other.

**Where It's Used**

* **Large Language Models:** RoPE is used in many state-of-the-art large language models.
* **Transformer-based Architectures:** It's particularly useful in models that rely on the transformer architecture.

Below is a detailed breakdown of its appearance, stylistic details, functionality, and user interface/experience (UI/UX):

---

### **Appearance and Style**
- **Typography**: The site uses the "Libre Baskerville" serif font, conveying a sense of elegance and readability.
- **Colour Palette**: 
  - **Light Mode**: A neutral background (`#f1f0e9`), dark primary text (`#172318`), and soft green accents (`#94C19E`) for secondary elements like hover effects and indicators.
  - **Dark Mode**: A deep black background (`#121212`), light text (`#e0e0e0`), and analogous green accents (`#81C784`).
  - Smooth transitions are applied for background and text colours when switching between modes.
- **Interactive Elements**: Subtle animations and transitions enhance interactivity:
  - Hover effects expand underlines and fill circular indicators.
  - Selected choices are highlighted with dynamic background and border changes.
- **Layout**: The site employs a centred, vertical layout for core content with a minimalist yet structured alignment. Ample spacing ensures clarity and focus.

---

### **Functionality**
- **Dynamic Questionnaire Flow**:
  - Questions are dynamically loaded based on user interactions.
  - Each question includes plain text interspersed with clickable keywords that reveal additional context or explanations in a floating info box.
  - Choices are presented as clickable cards, and selecting one advances the user to the next question or action.
  - The flow branches based on user responses using a JSON-structured decision tree.
- **Interactive Features**:
  - Clicking highlighted text triggers a tooltip-like info box providing contextual definitions or descriptions.
  - A "something else" option, when selected, introduces a timer-based delay before revealing an input field for custom answers, encouraging users to reconsider predefined choices.
- **End States**:
  - A summary page recaps user responses with a structured, scrollable overview.
  - An end state displays a static message if the user exits prematurely.
- **Night Mode Toggle**:
  - Users can switch between light and dark themes via a toggle switch in the bottom-left corner.
  - The toggle retains the selected mode using local storage.

---

### **UI/UX Specific Details**
- **Accessibility and Usability**:
  - Clear font and colour contrast ensure readability.
  - Elements such as buttons and choices have large, clickable areas with clear visual feedback on hover or selection.
- **Transitions and Animations**:
  - Smooth opacity transitions when loading questions improve visual flow.
  - Hover effects and animations, such as expanding underlines or changing button states, provide intuitive cues about interactivity.
- **Responsive Design**:

- **Guidance and Constraints**:
  - A subtle timer discourages impulsive selections, while disabling submission buttons for incomplete actions prevents errors.

The site serves as an exploratory questionnaire or survey tool, focusing on introspection and informed decision-making. Its thoughtful design encourages users to engage deeply with the content, reflect on their choices, and proceed at their own pace.

keyboard shortcuts|||create a data grid with search, edit and filter for data from https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts|||Build a tanstack table with resizeable columns, filters, pagination and column pinning|||DataTable Component Specification
Overview
A performant React DataTable component for displaying and manipulating tabular data with sorting, filtering, and pagination capabilities.
Core Features
Data Handling

Display tabular data with typed column definitions
Support dynamic updates and large datasets
Virtual scrolling for performance

Required Functionality

Sorting: Single/multi-column with custom sort functions
Filtering: Text, numeric, date ranges
Pagination: Client/server-side
Selection: Single/multi-row
Column Management: Resize, reorder, hide/show

Technical Interface
typescriptCopyinterface DataTableProps<T> {
  data: T[]
  columns: ColumnDefinition<T>[]
  pageSize?: number
  defaultSort?: SortConfig
  onSort?: (config: SortConfig) => void
  onFilter?: (filters: FilterConfig[]) => void
  onPageChange?: (page: number) => void
  onRowSelect?: (rows: T[]) => void
}

interface ColumnDefinition<T> {
  id: string
  header: string
  accessor: keyof T | ((row: T) => any)
  sortable?: boolean
  filterable?: boolean
  width?: number | string
  cellRenderer?: (value: any, row: T) => React.ReactNode
}
Implementation Requirements
Performance

Row virtualization for large datasets
Memoized sorting/filtering
Debounced user input
Optimized re-rendering

Accessibility

Keyboard navigation
ARIA attributes
Screen reader support
Focus management

Error Handling

Data validation
Graceful error recovery
Type checking

<web_designer_prompt>
<title>Interactive Variable Editor for Prompts</title>
<introduction>
We need a design for a feature that allows users to easily view and modify variables within prompt text. These variables will be enclosed in specific XML-like tags. The goal is to create a user-friendly interface for interacting with these variables.
</introduction>
<feature_description>
Implement a side panel (or a similar interactive element) that dynamically detects and displays variables defined within the following XML-like tags:
<variable_start color="#FF0000"><variable name="[variable_name]"></variable_start>
<variable_end color="#FF0000"></variable></variable_end>

The side panel should:
<functionality>
<item>Auto-detect variables based on the defined tags in the main prompt text.</item>
<item>Display each detected variable with its current value in an editable field.</item>
<item>Allow users to directly modify the value of each variable through the editable field.</item>
<item>Enable users to manually input new variable values within the editable field, respecting the tag structure.</item>
<item>Visually highlight the variable tags in the main prompt text using the specified <variable_start/> and <variable_end/> tag colors (red in this case).</item>
</functionality>
</feature_description>
<example>
Consider the following prompt text:

This is a prompt about <variable name="animal">cats</variable>. We will talk about their <variable name="color">fur</variable> and playful behavior.

The side panel should display:

Variable: animal
Value: cats

Variable: color
Value: fur

Modifying the "Value" field in the side panel should update the corresponding variable in the main prompt text. For example, changing "cats" to "dogs" should update the prompt to:

This is a prompt about <variable name="animal">dogs</variable>. We will talk about their <variable name="color">fur</variable> and playful behavior.
</example>
<design_considerations>
<item>The side panel should be easily accessible and not obstruct the main prompt text.</item>
<item>The visual highlighting of the variable tags in the main prompt should be clear and intuitive.</item>
<item>The editable fields in the side panel should provide clear feedback to the user when a variable is modified.</item>
<item>Consider how to handle potential errors in manually inputted variable tags.</item>
</design_considerations>
</web_designer_prompt>|||Design the world's best prompt playgournd, where user can compare different modles and prompts in the same interface. Here's a concise breakdown of a UI for a prompt selection system with the features you described, focusing on wrapping user-provided text within pre-built or generated prompts containing variables:

Core Concept:  The UI centers around a three-part workflow:

User Text Input: Where the user provides the text they want to use.
Prompt Selection/Generation: Choosing a pre-built prompt or creating one with a generator.
Variable Mapping: Plugging the user's text into designated variables within the chosen prompt.
UI Elements:

Text Input Area:

A clear, prominent text box labeled "Your Text" or "Input Text."
Possibly with options to upload a file or paste from the clipboard.
Prompt Selection/Generation Panel:

Two Tabs:
"Pre-built Prompts":
A browsable/searchable list of ready-to-use prompts.
Categorization/filtering (e.g., by task, style, tone).
Preview of the prompt structure with clearly marked variable placeholders (e.g., {{variable_1}}, [INPUT TEXT HERE]).
Selection highlights the chosen prompt.
"Use This Prompt" button proceeds to variable mapping.
"Generate Prompt":
Guided prompt builder.
Input fields or dropdowns for specifying desired prompt characteristics (e.g., task, style, length, specific instructions).
"Template Instructions" section: Preset options or guidelines for structuring the generated prompt (e.g., "Act as a [ROLE]", "Write in the style of [PERSONA]", "Include [KEYWORDS]").
"Generate" button creates the prompt with marked variable placeholders.
"Use This Prompt" button proceeds to variable mapping.
Variable Mapping Area:

Displayed after a prompt is selected (either pre-built or generated).
The chosen prompt is shown with variable placeholders highlighted.
Beside each variable placeholder, there's a dropdown or an assign button:
Dropdown Option: If there are multiple user text inputs in step one it will list them (e.g., "User Text 1," "User Text 2"). The user selects which text to insert into each variable.
"Assign" Button: If there is only one user text, it will indicate "user text" on the variable itself.

"Use This Prompt" or "Run" button to execute the prompt with the inserted text.

User Input: User pastes their text into the "Your Text" area.

The user clicks "Preview Final Prompt" to see:
Write a short summary of the following text: [User's Text Here]. Make it no longer than three sentences.
The user clicks "Use This Prompt."
Key Features:

Clear Visual Cues: Use distinct colors, highlighting, or icons to differentiate between user text input, prompt structure, and variable placeholders.
Intuitive Variable Mapping: Make it very easy to understand which text goes where. The dropdown method is generally preferred for its simplicity.
Error Prevention: Prevent users from proceeding if variables are not mapped correctly.
Flexibility: Allow users to edit the generated or pre-built prompt text directly before the final execution, if needed.
Optional Enhancements:

Prompt History: Keep a history of used prompts for quick re-use.
Prompt Rating/Favorites: Allow users to rate pre-built prompts and save their favorites.
